bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Mona Rose or Alice Forbes, July 31, 1952

div1.p: Hench asks Rose and Forbes, whom he visited ten years ago, for the correct middle name of Wallace Forbes, so that it may be placed on the Camp Lazear memorial tablet. He also inquires as to the whereabouts of Wallace Forbes.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Mona Rose or Alice Forbes, July 31, 1952
div1.opener:
July 31, 1952
Miss Mona Rose, or
Mrs. Alice Forbes
5450 Walton Street
Chicago, Illinois
Dear Friends:
div1.p:
Ten years ago I visited you because of my interest in Wallace W. Forbes.
You were very kind to me and we had a pleasant visit. I learned of
course that Mr. Forbes, who had been one of Major Walter Reed's volunteers,
for the yellow fever experiments in Cuba, had disappeared. You gave me
certain information and I tried to make inquiries through certain sources
but learned nothing. Now I write you for a little information.

The Cuban Government is about to erect a memorial at “Camp Lazear” where
the work was done, just outside Havana. They are setting up a bronze memorial
tablet and have asked me to give them the correct names of the various
American volunteers. I am not sure of the middle name of Mr. Forbes.
I have a copy of the radio program, “The Court of Missing Heirs,” given
September 23, 1941. In this script Mr. Forbes' name is given as
Wallace Wellington Forbes. Is this correct? We certainly want it to be
spelled correctly on the bronze tablet in Havana.

One more question. I have heard a rumor from someone else who is also
interest in the yellow fever story that Mr. Forbes had been found but that
he had died recently. I would appreciate it if you would give me some
brief information regarding this.

In view of the fact that the Cuban Government expects to dedicate the
bronze tablet in September, they will need very quickly Mr. Forbes'
correct name.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
Write re recent news re death; fr at pick
" " middle name.
